instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN_R: What is P5VS4RS3_EN_R? P5VS4RS3_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message: 820 3435 no power, machine was liquid damaged, but over all the board looks to be in decant shape. I have G3 rails, I have s5 rails, missing s4. 0.00v on <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_R</SIGNAL>, also 0.00v <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message:
Green/orange light present?

The usual culprits checked, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>/1950/6100. PPVRTC present?

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message:
Yes, i have light on mag safe, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> should be good, I get 3.324v on PPVRTC

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
pin 1 0.053v
pin 2 0.061v
pin 3 0.000v
pin 4 0.000v
pin 5 0.025v
pin 6 0.025v
pin 7 0.003v
pin 8 0.000v

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message:
Check carefully if there is power cycling on P5VS4RS3. Pluses will be very short and hard to catch on multimeter, best to use a scope. Checked all rails for shorts?

Pin 8 corroded on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is also a common problem that will cause power cycling/pulsing.

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message: Unfortunately I do not have a scope, with my fluke, it says 0v, but like you said maybe hard to catch. Pin 8 on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> looks great. Yes, I checked all rails for shorts.

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message: Can you post a good clear picture of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>/<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> area?

threads.title: 820 3435 No Power
threads.message: Looks ok. Well without a scope we can only stab in the dark. Corrosion under SMC? Give it a light reflow with some flux, not full just 150C and let it cook a bit.
